revision.text:
[[Image:Icexcellence chosen artists.jpg|thumb|IcExcellence chosen artists]]
The '''Israel Cultural Excellence Foundation''' (IcExcellence) is a private cultural foundation which aims to identify, nurture, and support [[Israel]]'s most outstanding artists.
The foundation locates Israeli artists with potential for excellence in a wide variety of artistic fields, including [[visual arts]], music (classical, jazz, and Israeli), dance, theater, cinema, [[product design]], [[visual communication]], fashion design, and writing. The foundation supports its chosen artists for a period of up to five years.<ref>[http://www.icexcellence.com//emppage.asp?id=81 The chosen people, Aviva Lori, [[Haaretz]]]</ref>
==The foundation== IcExcellence was founded by its managing director Rachel Marani, formerly Israel’s cultural [[attaché]] in [[Washington, DC|Washington]]. It is financed by businesspeople, companies, and foundations from Israel and all over the world.
The artistic advisory committees consist of 35 artists and public opinion makers, including six [[Israel Prize]] laureates, all acting on a voluntary basis. Members include Dubi Lenz, Gal Uchovsky, [[David Tartakover]], Michal Smoira-Cohn, [[Chaim Topol]], [[Dani Caravan]], Yossi Marhaim, [[Mendi Rodan]], [[Ohad Naharin]], Danny Gottfried, Ron Arad, Asher Fisch, Gershon Bram, Alex Padua, and Micha Lewensohn.
The work of the foundation focuses on two main areas. The first, "Developing and advancing the artist’s knowledge and skills", involves building a personal advancement program suited to the artist and their needs. The programs may include taking advanced courses in a foreign country, or learning a relevant professional software program. The second area, "Developing and advancing the artist’s professional career, involves encouraging artists to assume a proactive approach to advancing their careers, based on the understanding that great artistic talent is a prerequisite but in itself does not suffice for developing a prominent local and/or international career. Seminars and annual meetings deal with “career skills”, exposing the artists to subjects such as strategic and business counseling, self-presentation, marketing, branding, and networking. Business coaching is also offered.
== IcExcellence Chosen Artists, 2002-08== ===Israeli Music===
[[Din Din Aviv]], [[David D'Or]], Lior Elmalich, Victoria Hanna, [[Rona Kenan]], Ron Shem Tov ([[Izabo]]), Shlomi Shaban
===Classical Music===
[[File:תמונה ירון גוטפריד.JPG|thumb|140px|Yaron Gottfried]] [[File:Etgar-keret-photo-by-moti-kikayon.jpg|thumb|140px|[[Etgar Keret]]]] Conductors [[Gil Shohat]], [[Dan Ettinger]], and Yaron Gottfried, Opera Singer Chen Reiss, Composer [[Avner Dorman]], Keren Hadar
===Jazz===
Avishai Cohen, Eli Degibri
===Theater===
Actor Itay Tiran, Set & Lighting Designer Bambi Friedman, [[Mira Awad]], Keren Zur
===Writing===
Author [[Etgar Keret]], [[Eshkol Nevo]]
===Film & Television===
Directors Nir Bergman, Tomer Heymann, David Ofek,
===Visual Art===
[[Yael Bartana]], Zoya Cherkassky, [[Adi Nes]], Talia Keinan, Yehudit Sasportas, Gal Weinstein
===Visual Communication===
Graphic Designer Adi Stern, Illustrator [[Rutu Modan]]
===Fashion Design===
Avshalom Gur, [[Yaniv Persy]], Mirit Weinstock, Claudette Zorea,
===Choreography & Dance===
Sharon Eyal, Emanuel Gat, Yasmeen Godder, Idit Herman (Clipa Theater),
===Product Design===
Ron Gilad, Tal Gur
===Multi-Disciplinary=== Ohad Fishof
==See also== *[[Music of Israel]] *[[Dance in Israel]] *[[Culture in Israel]] *[[Cinema of Israel]]
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == *[http://www.icexcellence.com IcExcellence website] *[http://www.israel21c.org/bin/en.jsp?enScript=PrintVersion.jsp&enDispWho=Articles%5El2185 Finding Excellence in Israel's Artists]
[[Category:Israeli culture]]

[[File:Jug Bogdan and sons.jpg|thumb|''Jug Bogdan and the Nine Jugović'', work by [[Adam Stefanović]].]] The '''Jugović brothers''' ({{lang-sr|Браћа Југовићи}}), or '''Nine Jugović''' (Девет Југовића), commonly known as the '''''Jugovići''''', the nine sons of [[Jug Bogdan]] ([[Vratko Nemanjić]]), are popular mythological characters of [[Serbian epic poetry]]. In poems, the Jugović brothers and their [[blood brother]] [[Miloš Obilić]] fight to their death in the [[Battle of Kosovo]] (1389), dying as heroes.<ref name="Segesten2011">{{cite book|author=Anamaria Dutceac Segesten|title=Myth, Identity, and Conflict: A Comparative Analysis of Romanian and Serbian Textbooks|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1SmTBNe0q2sC&pg=PA208|date=16 September 2011|publisher=Lexington Books|isbn=978-0-7391-4865-5|pages=208–209}}</ref> This is based on mythology, in which Miloš Obilić and other knights lost their life "in glory as martyrs".<ref name="Segesten2011"/> One of the earliest accounts of the battle was the Florentine chancellor [[Coluccio Salutati]] (died 1406) who described twelve Christian noblemen who broke through the Ottomans, one of whom killed the Sultan (in later accounts, that knight was named identified as Miloš Obilić).<ref>{{harvnb|Emmert|1996}}; {{citation|author=V. V. Makušev|title=Prilozi k srpskoj istoriji XIV i XV veka|work=Glasnik srpskog učenog društva'' 32|year=1871|pages=174–5}}</ref>
The brothers have been depicted in the arts, such as by Croatian painter [[Mirko Rački]],<ref>{{cite book|author=Dejan Djokić|title=Yugoslavism: Histories of a Failed Idea, 1918-1992|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZMyZdvTympMC&pg=PA232|date=January 2003|publisher=C. Hurst & Co. Publishers|isbn=978-1-85065-663-0|p=232}}</ref> Serbian painter [[Adam Stefanović]], and on a [[mosaic]] on the [[Tronoša Monastery]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dizajnplanina.com/manastir-tronosa-na-izvoru-koji-otvara-oci/}}</ref> which is popularly associated with the Jugovići.<ref>{{cite book|author=Mladen Stojanović|title=Socialist Republic of Serbia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rb0MAAAAIAAJ|year=1970|publisher=Export-Press|p=324}}</ref>
The [[Serbian Church]] awards [[Order of the Mother of Jugović|an order]] to mothers of more than four children, named after the mother of the Jugović brothers.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Joyce P. Kaufman|author2=Kristen P. Williams|title=Women, the State, and War: A Comparative Perspective on Citizenship and Nationalism|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jZYoqtMnA-UC&pg=PA87|date=24 December 2007|publisher=Lexington Books|isbn=978-0-7391-6261-3|page=87}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Nine Brothers Kherkheulidze]] from [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]], killed in the [[Battle of Marabda]] against [[Safavid Empire]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==Sources== * {{Citation |last=Emmert |first=Thomas A. |title=Milos Obilic and the Hero Myth|journal=Journal of the North American Society for Serbian Studies |volume=10 |year=1996 |url=http://www.deremilitari.org/resources/articles/emmert.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100213043053/http://www.deremilitari.org/resources/articles/emmert.htm |archivedate=2010-02-13}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Jugovic brothers}} [[Category:Characters in Serbian epic poetry]] [[Category:Heroes in mythology and legend]] [[Category:Fictional knights]] [[Category:Martyrdom in fiction]]

revision.comment: Add: date. You can [[WP:UCB|use this bot]] yourself. [[WP:DBUG|Report bugs here]]. | [[WP:UCB|User-activated]].
revision.text:
{{Infobox philosopher | region = [[Western philosophy]] | era = [[20th-century philosophy|20th-]]/[[21st-century philosophy]] | image = Portrait of Kiarina Kordela.jpg | caption = | name = Kiarina Kordela | other_names = Aglaia Kiarina Kordela
A. Kiarina Kordela | birth_place = [[Patras]], [[Greece]] | birth_date = {{Birth date and age |1963|07|13}} | alma_mater = [[University of Athens]]
[[University of Pittsburgh]]
[[Cornell University]] | school_tradition = [[Continental philosophy]]
[[Critical theory]] | books = ''$urplus''
''Being, Time, Bios'' | main_interests = [[Psychoanalysis]], [[political philosophy]], [[literary theory]], [[film theory]] | notable_ideas = Ontosemiotics | influences = [[Baruch Spinoza]], [[Jacques Lacan]], [[Slavoj Žižek]] | influenced = }} {{Psychoanalysis|Schools}} '''Aglaia Kiarina Kordela''' ({{IPAc-en|k|ɔːr|ˈ|d|ɛ|l|ə}}; {{lang-el|Αγλαΐα Κιαρίνα Κορδέλα}} {{IPA-el|korˈðela|}}; born July 13, 1963) is a Greek-American [[philosopher]] and [[critical theorist]]. She is a professor of [[German Studies]] and founding director of the Critical Theory Program at [[Macalester College]] in [[Saint Paul, Minnesota|Saint Paul, MN]]. She is also Honorary Adjunct Professor at the Writing and Society Research Center, [[University of Western Sydney]], Australia. She writes and teaches on a wide range of topics, notably [[psychoanalysis]], political, literary and [[film theory]], and [[Biopower|biopolitics]]. Her primary approach and focus is on the relation between [[economic system|economic structures]] and [[metaphysics]] in [[secular]] [[capitalist]] [[modernity]].{{cite web |url=http://www.macalester.edu/academics/criticaltheory/facultystaff/kordela/ |title =A. Kiarina Kordela Faculty Page |website=Macalester College, Critical Theory |accessdate=20 June 2013 }} Kordela is known for her reinterpretation of [[Lacanian psychoanalysis]] and [[Michel Foucault|Foucauldian]] [[biopolitics]] using the work of [[Baruch Spinoza|Spinoza]]. Her philosophical inquiries have ramifications for a variety of contemporary social issues and academic fields of study, including [[Postcolonialism|Postcolonial Studies]], [[Critical Race Theory]], [[Critical Terrorism Studies]], [[Comparative Literature]], and [[Film Studies]]. == Biography == === Early life === Kordela was born in Patras, Greece to a middle- to lower-class family of Greek and Italian descent. She moved out of her family's home at the age of 18 (far earlier than is traditional Greek custom), studied filmmaking and worked as a stewardess and bartender. At age 23, she began undergraduate studies in the Department of German Language and Literature at the Philosophy School of Athens at the [[National and Kapodistrian University of Athens|University of Athens]]. Having fulfilled her degree requirements a year earlier than stipulated, she received a [[German Academic Exchange Service|DAAD]] scholarship for a year of studies at [[Heidelberg University]], Germany. A similar scenario occurred during her graduate studies: "I eventually went to Cornell where I did my PhD. I had six years of financial support at Cornell, but I finished in four years."{{cite web |url=http://specimenmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/Kiarina-Kordela-for-Specimen.pdf |title= Interview with Kiarina Kordela |website=Specimen Magazine |accessdate=20 June 2013}} === Education === Kordela received her B.A. from [[University of Athens]], Greece and her M.A. from [[University of Pittsburgh]]. She received her Ph.D. from [[Cornell University]] in 1998. Kordela has been teaching at Macalester since 1998. Professor Kordela teaches regularly courses in English toward both the German major/minor and the Critical Theory concentration, such as the core Critical Theory seminars "Dead White Men," and a series of different topics seminars, such as "Metaphysics in Secular Thought," "German-French Dialogues in Critical Theory," Value" (a course on aesthetic theory, in its relation to economic and ethical values), ” "Modernity and the Unconscious," "Modernism-Postmodernism," "A Kafkaesque Century," “Philosophy, Literature, Film,” as well as courses on film theory. == Overview of works == === ''$urplus'' (2007) === In 2007, Kordela published ''$urplus: Spinoza, Lacan'', wherein she maintains that the work of [[Psychoanalysis|Psychoanalyst]] [[Jacques Lacan]] is the correct continuation of thought that runs through Spinoza and Marx.Kordela, A. Kiarina. 2007. ''$urplus''. Albany, NY: SUNY Press. 2. {{ISBN|0791470199}} She argues that this line of thought entails a radical reconceptualization of Being or appearance,Kunkle, Sheila. "Review: $urplus: Spinoza, Lacan." ''Rethinking Marxism: A Journal of Economics, Culture and Society'' 22.1 (2010): pp. 157. and further, that this new ontology works "not simply to overturn the Platonic hierarchy but collapses it as obsolete."Kordela, A. Kiarina. 2007. ''$urplus''. Albany, NY: SUNY Press. 46. Kordela challenges certain interpretations of Spinoza (namely, those of [[Jonathan Israel]], [[Gilles Deleuze]], [[Félix Guattari]], [[Antonio Negri]], and [[Michael Hardt]]). Although Kordela criticizes these readings of Spinoza, she also argues that popular criticisms of neo-spinozism (e.g. those of [[Slavoj Žižek]] and [[Alain Badiou]]) make the same mistake as those they criticize — both sides ignore the inherent contradictions of Spinoza's work. One of those contradictions, which is central to Kordela analysis of Spinoza and her allegiance to his monism, is his statement that "truth is the standard both of itself and the false."Spinoza, Baruch (Benedict de). 1992. ''Ethics''. Transl. Samuel Shirley. Ed. Seymoir Feldman. Indianapolis, IN: Hackett Publishing Company, Inc. Print. Part II, Prop. 43, Scholium 1. pp. 92. Kordela argues that this ternary concept of truth — truth, itself and the false — reveals Spinoza's break with the binaries of both Platonism and anti-Platonism. Kordela shows that this ternary structure corresponds to Lacan's argument that truth has the structure of a fiction.Lacan, Jacques. 2002. ''Écrits: A Selection.'' Transl. Bruce Fink. New York, NY: W. W. Norton & Company, Inc. Print. pp. 684. Kordela traces the emergence of “enjoyment” and “the gaze” out of Spinoza’s theories of God, truth, and causality, Kant’s critique of pure reason, and, drawing on [[Kojin Karatani]], Marx’s pathbreaking application of set theory to economy. The main achievement of ''$urplus'' is to move away from the logical impasse of Kant's critique of reason to Lacan's and Marx's theories of surplus by way of set theory.Kunkle, Sheila. "Review: $urplus: Spinoza, Lacan." ''Rethinking Marxism: A Journal of Economics, Culture and Society'' 22.1 (2010): pp. 158 === ''Being, Time, Bios'' (2013) === Although both share a focus on human life as it is inscribed by power, Foucauldian biopolitics and Lacanian psychoanalysis have remained isolated from and even opposed to one another. In ''Being, Time, Bios'', A. Kiarina Kordela aims to overcome this divide, formulating a historical ontology that draws from Spinoza, Marx, Heidegger, and Sartre to theorize the changed character of being and time under secular capitalism. With insights from film theory, postcolonial studies, and race theory, Kordela s wide-ranging analysis suggests a radically new understanding of contemporary capitalism one in which uncertainty, sacrifice, immortality, and the gaze are central. == Publications == To date, Kordela has authored two monographs, co-edited two others, and many articles in academic journals and anthological collections. She has also translated a number of academic texts into [[Modern Greek]]. === Books === * 2013, ''Being, Time, Bios: Capitalism and Ontology'', Albany: SUNY Press (Ed. Charles Shepherdson) * 2011, ''Freedom and Confinement in Modernity: Kafka’s Cages'', New York: Palgrave-Macmillan (with [[Dimitris Vardoulakis]]) * 2007, ''$urplus: Spinoza, Lacan'', Albany: SUNY Press (Ed. Charles Shepherdson) ==== Forthcoming works ==== The following books have been announced, but not yet published.{{cite web |url=http://kiarinakordela.wordpress.com/curriculum-vitae/ |title=Publications by Kiarina Kordela |website=Kiarina Kordela's personal website |accessdate=20 June 2013|date=2009-10-26 }} * ''Ontosemiotics: Words, Things, Bios, and (Im)Mortality'' === Articles === ==== in English ==== {| width="100%" cellspacing="12" style="font-size:12px" |----- valign="top"| | style="vertical-align:top" width="50%"| * 2013, [http://differences.dukejournals.org/content/24/1/1.abstract “Biopolitics, From Tribes to Commodity Fetishism”] in ''Differences'' 24.1 (2013): pp. 1–29. * 2012, [http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/0969725X.2012.701048#.UcIrvPaDQZ4 “Being or Sex, and Differences”] in ''Angelaki'' 17.2 (2012): pp. 49–67. * 2012, "The Surplus Gaze of Legibility: Guilt, Ethics, and Out-of-Field in Deleuze, Lacan, and Žižek" in ''Psychoanalyzing Cinema: A Productive Encounter of Lacan, Deleuze, and Žižek''. Ed. Jan Jagodzinski. Palgrave (2012), pp. 227–245. * 2012, [http://kiarinakordela.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/racismumbra1.pdf (Psychoanalytic) Biopolitics, and Bioracism”] * 2011, [http://digitalcommons.macalester.edu/macintl/vol27/iss1/14/ “Bioracism, Or, Spiritual Evolutionism”] in ''Macalester International'' 24. * 2011, “A Thought Beyond Dualisms, Creationist and Evolutionist Alike” in ''Spinoza Now''. Ed. Dimitris Vardoulakis, University of Minnesota Press. * 2010, [https://www.scribd.com/doc/48883387/MythsPostmodernCultCrit “Four Fundamental Myths of Postmodern Thought (Or, The Eclipse of the Gaze)”] Cultural Critique 75 (Spring 2010): pp. 1–30. * 2009, [http://works.bepress.com/a_kiarina_kordela/8/ “Even Less: Antinomies and Aesthetic Anorexia in the Magnetic Fields’ 69 Love Songs (An Album For Boys AndGirls).”] * 2009, “Desire and Trauma on Credit: Lacan, Antigone, and Democracy.” Special issue on Jacques Lacan of the Turkish/English journal Monokl, 3: 6-7 (2009): pp. 101–12 (Turkish Translation). * 2008, “The Gaze of Biocinema”, in ''European Film Theory.'' Ed. Temenuga Trifonova, New York: Routledge, pp. 151–164. * 2008. “Genre With and Beyond Gender and Sex (a Psychoanalytic Intervention)”, in ''Angelaki'' (special issue on Re-Coupling Gender and Genre) 13:2 (August 2008): pp. 93–107. * 2007, [http://muse.jhu.edu/login?auth=0&type=summary&url=/journals/cultural_critique/v065/65.1kordela.html “Marx’s Update of Cultural Theory”], ''Cultural Critique'' (special issue on Cultures of Finance) 65 (Winder 2007): pp. 44–66. | style="vertical-align:top" width="50%"| * 2007, “Marx, Condensed and Displaced”, in ''The Dreams of Interpretation: A Century Down the Royal Road''. Ed. Catherine Liu, John Mowitt, Thomas Pepper, and Jackie Spice. Minneapolis, MN: The University of Minnesota Press. pp. 303–319. * 2006, [http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/08935690600901202?journalCode=rrmx20#.UcJAOPaDQZ4 “Capital: At Least It Kills Time (Spinoza, Marx, Lacan, and Temporality)”], in ''Rethinking Marxism'' 18:4 (October 2006): pp. 539–563. * 2005, [http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/13534640500133971#.UcJAifaDQZ4 “Grammar of Secsual and Visceral Reason”], in ''Parallax'' (special issue on “Visceral Reason”) 11:3 (July–September 2005): pp. 55–71. * 2005, [http://digitalcommons.macalester.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1401&context=macintl “Secular Faith: Beyond Postmodern Reason and Religious Belief”] in ''Macalester International'' 15 (Winter 2005): pp. 210–230. * 2002, “The Democratic Father: Credit and Crime in Metaphor”, in ''Literary Paternity—Literary Friendship: Essays in Honor of Stanley Corngold.'' Ed. Gerhard Richter. Chapel Hill, NC: The University of North Carolina Press. pp. 354–381. * 2001, [https://www.jstor.org/discover/10.2307/3195280?uid=2&uid=4&sid=21102345474771 “It Looks Down Upon Us: Allegorical Fields and Repetitive Errors”] in ''Modern Language Studies'' (special issue on Goethe) 31:1 (Spring 2001): pp. 99–129. * 1999, [https://www.jstor.org/discover/10.2307/192247?uid=2&uid=4&sid=21102345474771 “Political Metaphysics: God in Global Capitalism (The Slave, the Masters, Lacan, and the Surplus”] in ''Political Theory'' 27: 6 (December 1999): pp. 789–839. * 1999, “Exteriority to Metaphor”, in ''Hihuo kukan'' 2.12 (1999): pp. 112–131. (Japanese translation) * 1988, “The Life and Work of E. T. A. Hoffmann”, Introduction to the bilingual (German-Greek) edition of E. T. A. Hoffmann’s ''Spielerglück.'' Trans. Costas Kariotakis. Athens, Greece: Exantas. pp. 1–15. |} === Texts translated === ==== From English to Greek ==== * 1992, “The Foundings of the Arts. Private Support — Freedom of Expression — Government Responsibility.” Roger Ackling, ''Arti'' 3:4 (Winter 1992): pp. 29–38. * 1992, “Ideas for a Museum of Modern Art: Following the Example of the Dublin Institute of Modern Art (IMA).” Roger A. Wollen, ''Arti'' 3:2 (Summer 1992): pp. 32–40. * 1992, “[[Miltos Manetas]] and the Greek Modern Art” Paolo Bicco, ''Arti'' 3:1 (Spring 1992): pp. 14–21. ==== From German to Greek ==== * 1992, “Die Konstruktion der Erfahrungswelt: Karnap—Husserl.” Verena Meyer, ''Deucalion'' 11:1 (October 1992): pp. 51–68. * 1992, “Figura.” Erich Auerbach, ''Logou Harin'' 2:2 (January 1992): pp 24–39. * 1992, “In the Realm of Free Spirit: Pursuing a Higher Common Element.” Werner Haftmann, ''Arti'' 3:4 (Winter 1992): pp. 9–15. * 1992, “Vlassis Kaniaris und die Kunst der Gastarbeiter.” Werner Haftmann, ''Arti'' 3:1 (Spring 1992): pp. 31–39. * 1991, “Alter Wein in neuen Schläuchen: Bemerkungen zum New-Historicism.” Hans-Robert Jauß, ''Logou Harin'' 2:1 (September 1991): pp. 12–20. == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://vimeo.com/37135130 Kiarina Kordela as a panelist] in "Free For(u)m Salon: #PartyMBT- The American Dream: A Dream Deferred? on Vimeo" * [http://mixedbloodblog.wordpress.com/2012/04/04/crashing-the-party-or-a-postmodern-death-of-a-salesman-guest-blog-post/ Guest post by Kiarina Kordela] for [[Mixed Blood Theatre Company]] * Kiarina Kordela is an editorial board member of [http://www.upress.umn.edu/book-division/books/culture-clinic-1 Culture/Clinic], a journal of Applied Lacanian Psychoanalysis. {{Critical theory|state=uncollapsed}} {{continental philosophy|state=collapsed}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kordela, Kiarina}} [[Category:20th-century philosophers]] [[Category:21st-century philosophers]] [[Category:Continental philosophers]] [[Category:Critical race theory]] [[Category:Critical theorists]] [[Category:Cultural studies]] [[Category:Cornell University alumni]] [[Category:21st-century Greek philosophers]] [[Category:Structuralists]] [[Category:1963 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Macalester College faculty]]

[[File:KoriKoppu.jpg|320px|thumb|Kōrikoppu]] {{nihongo3||氷コップ|'''Kōrikoppu'''}} ([[:ja:氷コップ|ja]]) is dedicated [[glassware]] which was mainly used for {{nihongo3|Japanese shaved ice|かき氷|[[Kakigōri]]}} before World War II in Japan.
Early ''Kōrikoppu'' could be found by the end of the [[Meiji period]] (1868–1912), and individual texture patterns using a technique of aburidashi (a technique of glass-works that motifs come to the surface by difference in temperature) were developed<ref>{{cite book|last=INOUE|first=Akiko|title=About Kōrikoppu using a technique of aburidashi "The Japanese Glass-Vidro, diamante, glass, from the Edo period to the Meiji, Taisho era"|url=http://www.city.kobe.lg.jp/culture/culture/institution/museum/tokuten/told72.html|year=2000|publisher=Kobe City Museum|page=134}}</ref> until the beginning of the [[Shōwa period]] (1926–1989).
==See also== *[[Penny lick]] - an old small glass for serving ice cream in U.K.
==References== <references/>
{{DEFAULTSORT:Korikoppu}} [[Category:Glass art]] [[Category:Japanese culture]]

page.title: List of Latin Grammy Awards categories

revision.text:
The '''[[Latin Grammy Awards]]''' are awarded in a series of '''categories''', each of which isolate a specific contribution to [[Latin music (genre)|Latin music]]. The standard awards list nominees in each category from which a winner is selected. These categories have been added and removed over time.
==General Field== The General Field consists of four standard awards representing the best over-all achievements in performance, production, and songwriting in [[Spanish language|Spanish]] and [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] languages: *[[Latin Grammy Award for Record of the Year|Record of the Year]] is awarded to the performer and the production team of a single song. *[[Latin Grammy Award for Album of the Year|Album of the Year]] is awarded to the performer and the production team of a full album. *[[Latin Grammy Award for Song of the Year|Song of the Year]] is awarded to the writer(s)/composer(s) of a single song. *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best New Artist|Best New Artist]] is awarded to an artist without reference to a song or album.
==Genre-specific fields== ===Pop=== *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Contemporary Pop Vocal Album|Best Contemporary Pop Vocal Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Traditional Pop Vocal Album|Best Traditional Pop Vocal Album]]
''Previously awarded:'' *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Female Pop Vocal Album|Best Female Pop Vocal Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Male Pop Vocal Album|Best Male Pop Vocal Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Pop Album by a Duo or Group with Vocals|Best Pop Album by a Duo or Group with Vocals]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Pop Vocal Album|Best Pop Vocal Album]]
===Urban=== *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Urban Fusion/Performance|Best Urban Fusion/Performance]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Urban Music Album|Best Urban Music Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Urban Song|Best Urban Song]]
===Rock=== *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Rock Album|Best Rock Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Rock Song|Best Rock Song]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Pop/Rock Album|Best Pop/Rock Album]]
''Previously awarded:'' *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Rock Solo Vocal Album|Best Rock Solo Vocal Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Rock Vocal Album, Duo or Group|Best Rock Vocal Album, Duo or Group]]
===Alternative=== *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Alternative Music Album|Best Alternative Music Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Alternative Song|Best Alternative Song]]
===Tropical=== *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Salsa Album|Best Salsa Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Cumbia/Vallenato Album|Best Cumbia/Vallenato Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Contemporary Tropical Album|Best Contemporary Tropical Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Traditional Tropical Album|Best Traditional Tropical Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Tropical Fusion Album|Best Tropical Fusion Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Tropical Song|Best Tropical Song]]
''Previously awarded:'' *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Merengue Album|Best Merengue Album]]
===Singer-Songwriter=== *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Singer-Songwriter Album|Best Singer-Songwriter Album]]
===Regional Mexican=== *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Ranchero/Mariachi Album|Best Ranchero/Mariachi Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Banda Album|Best Banda Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Tejano Album|Best Tejano Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Norteño Album|Best Norteño Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Regional Mexican Song|Best Regional Mexican Song]]
''Previously awarded:'' *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Grupero Album|Best Grupero Album]]
===Instrumental=== *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Instrumental Album|Best Instrumental Album]]
===Traditional=== *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Folk Album|Best Folk Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Tango Album|Best Tango Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Flamenco Album|Best Flamenco Album]]
===Jazz=== *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Latin Jazz Album|Best Latin Jazz Album]]
===Christian=== *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Christian Album (Spanish Language)|Best Christian Album (Spanish Language)]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Christian Album (Portuguese Language)|Best Christian Album (Portuguese Language)]]
===Portuguese Language === *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Portuguese Language Contemporary Pop Album|Best Portuguese Language Contemporary Pop Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Portuguese Language Rock or Alternative Album|Best Portuguese Language Rock or Alternative Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Samba/Pagode Album|Best Samba/Pagode Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best MPB Album|Best MPB Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Sertaneja Music Album|Best Sertaneja Music Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Portuguese Language Roots Album|Best Portuguese Language Roots Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Portuguese Language Song|Best Portuguese Language Song]]
''Previously awarded:'' *Best Romantic Music Album
Note: The field was originally called "Brazilian" before it was changed to "Portuguese Language" in 2016.
===Children's=== *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Latin Children’s Album|Best Latin Children’s Album]]
===Classical=== *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Classical Album|Best Classical Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Classical Contemporary Composition|Best Classical Contemporary Composition]]
===Arrangement=== *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Arrangement|Best Arrangement]]
===Recording Package=== *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Recording Package|Best Recording Package]]
===Production=== *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Engineered Album|Best Engineered Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Producer of the Year|Producer of the Year]]
===Music video=== *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Short Form Music Video|Best Short Form Music Video]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Long Form Music Video|Best Long Form Music Video]]
==Special awards== There are special awards which are awarded without nominations, typically for achievements of longer than the past year, which the standard awards apply to:
*[[Latin Recording Academy Person of the Year|Person of the Year]] is a Special Merit Award presented to an individual who has had a significant effect on [[Latin music (genre)|Latin music]] and has taken part in extensive philanthropy. *[[Latin Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award|Lifetime Achievement Award]]: is a Special Merit Award presented to performers who have made creative contributions of outstanding artistic significance to the field of recording during their careers. *[[Latin Grammy Trustees Award|Trustees Awards]]: is a Special Merit Award presented to individuals who have made significant contributions, other than performance, to the field of recording during their careers. *[[Latin Grammy Hall of Fame Award|Hall of Fame Award]] honors recordings that are at least twenty-five years old that have made significant contributions
==References== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100926192400/http://latingrammy.com/en/pages/11-awards The Latin GRAMMY Award Categories] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100214061826/http://www.latingrammy.com/en/pages/12-awards The Latin GRAMMY Award Category Guidelines] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110713190418/http://www.latingrammy.com/en/pages/13-awards The Latin GRAMMY Special Awards]
{{Latin Grammy Awards}} {{Latin Grammy Awards categories}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Latin Grammy Awards categories}} [[Category:Latin Grammy Awards|.]] [[Category:Music-related lists]] [[Category:Latin Grammy Award categories| ]] [[Category:American music-related lists]]

revision.comment: Disambiguating links to [[Paulhan]] (link changed to [[Paulhan, Hérault]]) using [[User:Qwertyytrewqqwerty/DisamAssist|DisamAssist]].
revision.text:
{{For|an overview of early medieval watermills from 500 to 1000 AD|List of early medieval watermills}} [[File:Barbegal mill 02.jpg|thumb|250px|The [[Barbegal|Barbegal mill]], located on a steep slope in southern France, is considered the biggest [[ancient history|ancient]] mill complex. Its capacity was sufficient to feed the whole nearby city of [[Arles]].<ref>{{harvnb|Greene|2000|p=39}}</ref>]] [[File:Römische Sägemühle.svg|thumb|250px|Scheme of a water-driven [[Hierapolis sawmill|Roman sawmill at Hierapolis]], Asia Minor. The 3rd century mill is the earliest known machine to incorporate a [[Crank (mechanism)|crank]] and [[connecting rod]] mechanism.<ref name="Ritti, Grewe, Kessener 2000, 161"/>]]
This '''list of ancient watermills''' presents an overview of water-powered [[grain-mill]]s and industrial mills in the [[classical antiquity]] from their [[Hellenistic period|Hellenistic]] beginnings through the [[Roman Empire|Roman imperial]] period.
== Historical overview == The [[watermill]] is the earliest instance of a machine harnessing natural forces to replace human muscular labour (apart from the [[sail]]).<ref>{{harvnb|Wilson|2002|p=9}}</ref> As such it holds a special place in the [[history of technology]] and also in economic studies where it is associated with growth.<ref>{{harvnb|Wikander|2000a|p=371}}</ref>
The initial invention of the watermill appears to have occurred in the [[Hellenistic civilization|hellenized eastern Mediterranean]] in the wake of the [[conquests of Alexander the Great]] and the rise of [[History of science in Classical Antiquity#Hellenistic period|Hellenistic science and technology]].<ref name="invention"/> In the subsequent [[Ancient Rome|Roman]] era, the use of water-power was diversified and different types of watermills were introduced. These include all three variants of the vertical [[water wheel]] as well as the horizontal water wheel.<ref>{{harvnb|Wikander|2000a|pp=373–378}}; {{harvnb|Donners|Waelkens|Deckers|2002|pp=12–15}}</ref> Apart from its main use in grinding flour, water-power was also applied to pounding grain,<ref name="Trip hammer"/> crushing ore,<ref name="Wikander 2000b, 407"/> sawing stones<ref name="Sawmill"/> and possibly fulling and bellows for iron furnaces.<ref>{{harvnb|Wikander|2000b|pp=406f.}}</ref>
An increased research interest has greatly improved our knowledge of Roman watermill sites in recent years. Numerous archaeological finds in the western half of the empire now complement the surviving documentary material from the eastern provinces; they demonstrate that the breakthrough of watermill technology occurred as early as the 1st century AD and was not delayed until the onset of the [[Middle Ages]] as previously thought.<ref>{{harvnb|Wikander|1985|pp=151–154}}; {{harvnb|Wikander|2000a|pp=370–373}}; {{harvnb|Wilson|2002|pp=9–17}}; {{harvnb|Brun|2006|pp=7–9}}</ref> The data shows a wide spread of grain-mills over most parts of the empire, with industrial mills also being in evidence in both halves.<ref>{{harvnb|Wikander|2000a|pp=397–400}}</ref> Although the prevalence of grain-mills naturally meant that watermilling remained a typically rural phenomenon, it also rose in importance in the urban environment.<ref>{{harvnb|Wikander|2000a|p=379}}</ref>
The data below spans the period until ca. 500 AD. The vast majority dates to Roman times.
== Earliest evidence == Below the earliest ancient evidence for different types of watermills and the use of water-power for various industrial processes. Note: The Perachora watermill, near Loutraki, in Greece, is not included; it is considered the earliest watermill with physical remains. This list is continued for the early Middle Ages [[List of early medieval watermills#Earliest evidence|here]].

=== Millstones === The following list comprises stray finds of ancient [[millstones]]. Note that there is no way to distinguish millstones driven by water-power from those powered by animals turning a [[Capstan (nautical)|capstan]]. Most, however, are assumed to derive from watermills.<ref name="Wikander 2000a, 372">{{harvnb|Wikander|2000a|p=372}}</ref>

in [[South Glamorgan]] --> <ref name="Wikander 1985, 163–165"/> |[[Wales]] |Unspecified |Fragment of millstone |- |}
=== Water wheels and other components === Although more rare than the massive millstones, finds of wooden and iron parts of the mill machinery can also point to the existence of ancient watermills.<ref>{{harvnb|Wikander|1985|p=165}}</ref> Large stone mortars have been found at many mines; their deformations suggest automated [[Stamp mill|crushing mills]] worked by water wheels.<ref>{{harvnb|Burnham|1997|pp=332–336}}</ref>
{| class="wikitable sortable" style="margin:1px; border:1px solid #cccccc; " |----- align="left" valign="top" bgcolor="cccccc" ! width="20%" | '''Site''' ! width="10%" | '''Country''' ! width="30%" | '''Date <small>(or find context)</small>''' ! width="40%" | '''Remains''' |- |[[Great Chesterford]] <ref name="Wikander 1985, 163–165"/> |[[England]] |Early 5th century AD hoard |Iron spindle with three winged rynds |- |[[Silchester]] <ref name="Wikander 1985, 163–165"/> |[[England]] |Mid-4th century AD hoard |Iron spindle |- |[[Saint-Doulchard]] <ref>{{harvnb|Champagne|Ferdière|Rialland|1997}}; {{harvnb|Brun|2006|p=112}}</ref> |[[France]] |1/10 to c.50 AD |Paddles, mill-chamber posts |- |[[Conimbriga]] <ref name="Wilson 2002, 10"/> |[[Portugal]] |On display in museum, allegedly 1st century AD |Mill-wheel |- |[[Hagendorn]] <ref name="Wikander 2000a, 385"/> |[[Switzerland]] |Late 2nd century AD |Three undershot wheels |- |[[Dolaucothi]] <ref name="Wikander 2000b, 407"/> |[[Wales]] |1st and 2nd centuries AD |Stone anvil ([[Pumsaint|Carreg Pumsaint]]) nearby <!-- name "Carreg Pumsaint" not given by Wikander, but by Burnham 1997, pp. 332–336--> |- |}

page.title: List of museums with major collections in ethnography and anthropology

revision.comment: Rescued 1 archive link; reformat 2 links. [[User:GreenC/WaybackMedic_2.1|Wayback Medic 2.1]]
revision.text:
{{Anthropology of art}} This is a list of [[museum]]s with major [[Collection (museum)|collections]] in [[ethnography]] and [[anthropology]].
# [[University of Cambridge Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology]], [[Cambridge]], UK #: 800,000 objects<ref>[http://maa.cam.ac.uk]</ref> # [[Pitt Rivers Museum]], [[Oxford]], UK #: 500,000 objects<ref>[http://www.tangodiva.com/index.php?page=network&story_rev_id=507]</ref> # [[British Museum]], [[London]], UK #: 350,000 objects<ref>[http://www.thebritishmuseum.ac.uk/the_museum/departments/africa,_oceania_and_americas.aspx]</ref> # [[Horniman Museum]], London, UK #: 80,000 objects<ref>[http://www.horniman.ac.uk/collections/anthropology]</ref> #[[Powell Cotton Museum]], Kent, UK #: 30,000 objects<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cornucopia.org.uk/html/search/verb/GetRecord/5596 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-06-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130914082919/http://www.cornucopia.org.uk/html/search/verb/GetRecord/5596 |archivedate=2013-09-14 |df= }}</ref> # [[Musée du quai Branly]], [[Paris]], France #: 1,170,495 objects in 2014 including an iconotheque of about 700,000 pieces<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.quaibranly.fr/en/collections/permanent-collections/exploring-the-permanent-collections.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-11-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141129034509/http://www.quaibranly.fr/en/collections/permanent-collections/exploring-the-permanent-collections.html |archivedate=2014-11-29 |df= }}</ref> (plus a mediatheque of 260,000 and archives)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.quaibranly.fr/en/enseignement/the-media-library/the-mediatheque-collections/index.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-11-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141129040015/http://www.quaibranly.fr/en/enseignement/the-media-library/the-mediatheque-collections/index.html |archivedate=2014-11-29 |df= }}</ref> # [[Musée de l'Homme]], Paris, France #: 500,000 objects<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.museedelhomme.fr/projet/le-parcours-et-les-collections/les-collections |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-11-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141129090806/http://www.museedelhomme.fr/projet/le-parcours-et-les-collections/les-collections |archivedate=2014-11-29 |df= }}</ref> # [[Ethnological Museum of Berlin|Ethnological Museum]], [[Berlin]], Germany #: 500,000 objects<ref>[http://www.smb.spk-berlin.de/smb/sammlungen/details.php?lang=de&objectId=56&n=1&r=4]</ref> (In addition to Africa, Americas & Oceania, the museum embraces holdings from Asia (South, South-East, Far-East and North Asia), the Islamic World, the Children's Museum and the Museum for the Blind.) # [[State Museum of Ethnology|Staatliches Museum für Völkerkunde]], [[Munich]], Germany #: 150,000 objects<ref>[http://www.voelkerkundemuseum-muenchen.de/]</ref> # [[Museum of Ethnology, Vienna|Museum für Völkerkunde]], [[Vienna]], Austria #: 200,000 objects<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20070427055853/http://www.ethno-museum.ac.at/en/frameset.html]</ref> # [[Kunstkamera|Peter the Great Museum of Anthropology and Ethnography (Kunstkamera)]], St. Petersburg, Russia #: 1 117,000 objects<ref>[http://www.kunstkamera.ru/en/]</ref> # [[Russian Museum of Ethnography]], [[St. Petersburg]], Russia #: 500,000 objects<ref>[http://www.ethnomuseum.ru/]</ref> # [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]], [[New York City]], New York, USA #: 11,000 objects<ref>[http://www.metmuseum.org/Works_of_Art/introduction.asp?dep=5]</ref> # [[Phoebe Hearst Museum of Anthropology]], [[Berkeley, California]], USA #: 634,000 objects<ref>{{cite web |url=http://hearstmuseum.berkeley.edu/collections/collections.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-04-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070514085457/http://hearstmuseum.berkeley.edu/collections/collections.html |archivedate=2007-05-14 |df= }}</ref> (In addition to Africa, Americas & Oceania, the museum embraces holdings from Europe, Ancient Mediterranean, Ancient Egypt, Asia and a large media collection) # [[American Museum of Natural History]] Division of Anthropology, New York, USA #: 119,000 objects<ref>[http://anthro.amnh.org/anthro.html]</ref> # [[Museo Nacional de Antropología]] (National Museum of Anthropology), [[Mexico City]], Mexico #: 120,000 objects<ref>[http://dti.inah.gob.mx/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=536&Itemid=52]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> # [[Museo de Antropología de Xalapa]], Xalapa, Mexico. # [[Museum of Anthropology at UBC|Museum of Anthropology]] at the University of British Columbia, [[Vancouver]], BC, Canada #: 36,000 ethnographic objects and 535,000 archaeological objects<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.moa.ubc.ca/about/history.php |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-05-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100507183405/http://moa.ubc.ca/about/history.php |archivedate=2010-05-07 |df= }}</ref> # [[Canadian Museum of Civilization]], [[Ottawa]], Ontario, Canada #: 3.75 million artifacts<ref>[http://www.civilization.ca/cmc/explore/collections]</ref> # [[Berndt Museum of Anthropology]], Perth, Australia, 11,500 items. # [[National Museum of Ethnology (Japan)]], [[Osaka]], Japan #: 335,000 objects<ref>[http://www.minpaku.ac.jp/sites/default/files/english/aboutus/youran/pdf/youran2013_en30-47.pdf]</ref> # [[Mathers Museum of World Cultures]], [[Indiana University]], Bloomington, Indiana, USA #: 30,000 ethnographic objects, 10,000 photographs <ref> [http://www.mathers.indiana.edu/museumcoll.html]</ref> # [[Museu Antropológico Diretor Pestana (Brazil)]], [[Ijuí, Santa Cataria]], Brazil, 29.000 pieces # [[Museu Nacional de Etnologia]] (National Museum of Ethnology), [[Lisbon]], Portugal #: 40,000 objects<ref>[http://www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt/pt/museus-e-monumentos/rede-portuguesa/m/museu-nacional-de-etnologia/]</ref> # [[National Museum of Ethnology (Netherlands)]], [[Leiden]], Netherlands #: 200,000 objects with 500,000 pieces in the image and multimedia libraries and 40,000 books.<ref>[https://volkenkunde.nl/en?gclid=Cj0KCQiAjO_QBRC4ARIsAD2FsXPb8Qsi1UoVzmYOWdrabjhCIo2LyJvJ8k3rgFREAFSReQ0YkDilFfsaAgO6EALw_wcB]</ref>
==References== <references/>
[[Category:Ethnographic museums|*Major collections]] [[Category:Anthropology museums|*Major collections]] [[Category:Lists of museums|Ethnography and anthropology]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = Meludia | logo = | type = [[Société par actions simplifiée]] (SAS) | homepage = http://www.meludia.com | genre = [[Music technology]] | foundation = 2012 | founders = Bastien Sannac
Vincent Chaintrier | area_served = Worldwide | location = [[Paris, France]] | products = [[Web application]], [[Mobile application]] | services = [[E-learning]], [[Music Education]] | footnotes = }} '''Meludia''' is a French-based company that offers an online interactive [[education]] platform to master the fundamentals of [[music]]. The Meludia Method is based upon progressive interactive listening exercises, using two main frameworks designed by Vincent Chaintrier.{{cite web|last1=Mallia|first1=Mathias|title=‘Meludia is an essential service which will be offered for free’ – Prime Minister, Joseph Muscat|url=http://www.independent.com.mt/articles/2016-05-02/local-news/Meludia-is-an-essential-service-which-will-be-offered-for-free-Prime-Minister-Joseph-Muscat-6736157191|website=[[The Malta Independent]]|accessdate=29 April 2017}} *The SEMA model represents the 4 levels of music perception: [[Sensation (psychology)|Sensations]], [[Emotions]], [[Memory]], [[Analysis]]. *The 7 dimensions of music represent: [[rhythm]], [[spatialization]], [[Dynamics (music)|dynamic]], [[Musical form|form]], [[timbre]], [[melody]] and [[harmony]].{{cite web|title=Screw Music Theory, This Guy Claims the Best Way to Learn Music is by Using an App - Noisey|url=https://noisey.vice.com/en_uk/article/youneedtohearthis-screw-music-theory-this-guy-claims-the-best-way-to-learn-music-is-by-using-an-app|website=Vice|language=en-dk}} ==History== Bastien Sannac and Vincent Chaintrier co-founded Meludia in June 2012. Meludia was further developed in the [[Cent Quatre]], a public cultural incubator in Paris, before being commercially launched in 2014.{{cite web|last1=Roussel|first1=Frédérique|title=Meludia, atout pour la musique|url=http://next.liberation.fr/musique/2016/06/06/meludia-atout-pour-la-musique_1457680|website=[[Libération]]|accessdate=29 April 2017|language=fr}} Meludia is used at [[The Curtis Institute of Music]] in [[Philadelphia]].{{cite web|title=Curtis Institute of Music to deploy the French web-based music learning platform, Meludia: Meludia becomes the first online interactive educational method recognized by The Curtis Institute of Music|url=http://www.classicalsource.com/db_control/db_news.php?id=3528|publisher=Classical Music|accessdate=20 July 2016}} Meludia has also been deployed to entire populations by several countries, like [[Estonia]]{{cite web|last1=Alla|first1=Hendrik|title=Muusikaplatvorm Meludia teeb Eesti rahvale väärt jõulukingituse|url=http://kultuur.postimees.ee/3442787/muusikaplatvorm-meludia-teeb-eesti-rahvale-vaart-joulukingituse|website=[[Postimees]]|accessdate=29 April 2017|language=et}}, [[Malta]]{{cite web|title=Introducing a new way of learning music online: Meludia|url=https://www.gramophone.co.uk/classical-music-news/introducing-a-new-way-of-learning-music-online-meludia|website=[[Gramophone Magazine]]|accessdate=29 April 2017|language=en|date=2 December 2015}} and [[Canada]].{{cite news | url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/calgary/cpo-meludia-canada-150-music-eduation-1.4436943 | title=Free music education offered to all Canadians as Calgary Philharmonic teams up with online platform Meludia | work=CBC | author= | date=2017-12-07 | accessdate=2017-12-09}} ==Awards== *Gold Medal and Grand Prix award at the 2014 [[Louis Lépine#Concours Lépine|Concours Lépine for Innovation]].{{cite web|title=Apprendre la musique sans solfège? C'est possible|url=http://www.novaplanet.com/novamag/62334/apprendre-la-musique-sans-solfege-c-est-possible|website=[[Nova Press]]|accessdate=13 September 2016}}{{cite web|title=Meludia, le jeu et les émotions pour apprendre la musique|url=http://www.atlantico.fr/decryptage/meludia-jeu-et-emotions-pour-apprendre-musique-atlantico-business-1797629.html|publisher=[[Atlantico]]|accessdate=13 September 2016}} *Gold Medal and Grand Prix award at the 2014 European [[Louis Lépine#Concours Lépine|Concours Lépine for Innovation]].{{cite web|title=2014 Meludia receives the Gold Medal at the 2014 International Concours Lépine for Innovation|url=http://www.latribune.fr/start-up/20140922triba368b56bd/meludia-la-start-up-francaise-recompensee-au-concours-lepine-europeen.html|publisher=[[La Tribune]]}}{{cite web|title=Nous avons testé pour vous une application pour apprendre le solfège. Et ce n'est pas gagné|url=http://tempsreel.nouvelobs.com/video/20141023.OBS3028/nous-avons-teste-pour-vous-une-application-pour-apprendre-le-solfege-et-ce-n-est-pas-gagne.html|publisher=[[L'Obs]]|accessdate=13 September 2016|language=fr-FR}} *Grand Prix for cultural innovation at Fabfest Paris 2014. *Le Web 2013 - Semi-finalist.{{cite web|last1=Teffahi|first1=Fawaz|title=LeWeb est-il un évènement utile pour les start-up?|url=http://www.lefigaro.fr/secteur/high-tech/2014/12/09/32001-20141209ARTFIG00049-leweb-est-il-un-evenement-utile-pour-les-start-up.php|website=[[Le Figaro]]|accessdate=13 September 2016|language=fr-FR|date=9 December 2014}} *[[South by Southwest]] - [[SXSW Festival]] Finalists in 2015 SXSW Interactive Innovation Awards in [[Austin, Texas|Austin]], [[Texas]] in 2015.{{cite web|title=SXSW Interactive Reveals Finalists for 2015 SXSW Interactive Innovation Awards|url=https://www.sxsw.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/2015InnovationAwardsFinalistsFINAL.pdf|publisher=South by Southwest|accessdate=28 September 2016}} ==See also== * [[Learning music by ear]] * [[Ear training]] * [[Absolute pitch]] * [[Relative pitch]] * [[Audiation]] * [[Tonal memory]] * [[Musical aptitude]] * [[Music education for young children]] * [[Music theory]] * [[Solfège]] * [[List of music software]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.meludia.com Official Meludia website] * [https://www.uberchord.com/blog/ear-training-with-meludia/ Meludia review from the Uberchord blog] * [https://blog.musicteachershelper.com/develop-the-minds-ear-with-meludia/ Meludia review from Music Teachers Helper blog] [[Category:Online education]] [[Category:Music technology]] [[Category:Musical training software]] [[Category:Ear training]]

The '''Ministry of Education and Culture''' is a [[Cabinet (government)|Cabinet]] position in the [[Government agency|governments]] of several nations. In some nations the [[Ministry of Education]] and the [[Ministry of Culture]] are separate departments; in others, the Ministry of Education and Culture also includes Arts, Science, Sports, etc.
The Ministry is politically responsible for [[education]] and promoting and protecting [[Culture|cultural expression]].
==Ministries of Education and Culture by country==
* [[Ministry of Education and Culture (Cyprus)]] * [[Ministry of Education and Culture (Finland)]] * [[Ministry of Education and Culture (Indonesia)]] * [[Ministry of Education and Culture (Israel)]] A position that existed in 1949–1977, 1984–1990, 1992–1993, and is now the ''Ministry of Education''. * [[Ministry of Education and Culture (Mozambique)]] * [[Ministry of Education and Culture (Spain)]] A position that existed from 1996-2000 and is now the ''Ministry of Education''. * [[Ministry of Education and Culture (Somalia)]] * [[Ministry of Education and Culture (Tanzania)]] * [[Ministry of Education and Culture (Uruguay)]] * [[Ministry of Education and Culture (Philippines)]] A position that existed from 1978-2001 and is now the ''Department of Education''.
==Similarly named ministries in other countries==
* [[Ministry of Education (Austria)]] * [[Ministry of Education, Religious Affairs, Culture and Sports (Greece)]] * [[Ministry of Education, Science and Culture (Iceland)]] * [[Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology]], Japan * [[Ministry of Education, Culture, and Science (Mongolia)|Ministry of Education, Culture, Science, and Sports (Mongolia)]] * [[Ministry of Education, Culture and Science (Netherlands)]] * [[Ministry of Education, Research and Culture (Sweden)]] * [[Ministry of Education, Sport and Culture (Zimbabwe)]]
== See also ==
* [[Right to science and culture]] * [[Human rights]] * [[Right to education]] * [[Right to an adequate standard of living]] * [[Welfare rights]] * [[Right to education]] * [[Economic, social and cultural rights]] * [[Culture minister]] * [[Cultural genocide]] * [[Education minister]] * [[Ministry of Culture and Tourism (disambiguation)]]
{{Types of government minister}}
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Culture ministries| ]] [[Category:Education ministries| ]]

revision.text:
{{Use British English|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}}
[[File:Owle Schreame Award Skull.jpg|thumb|The engraved glass skull of the Owle Schreame Award]]
The '''Owle Schreame Awards''' were 2014 theatrical awards honouring innovation in classical theatre. They were awarded by [[Brice Stratford]] and his Owle Schreame theatre company in 2014 to commemorate the 450th anniversary of Shakespeare's birth.<ref>Hemley, Matthew. [http://www.thestage.co.uk/news/2014/07/new-awards-launched-honour-classical-theatre/ "New Awards Launched to Honour Classical Theatre"]. ''[[The Stage]]''. 30 July 2014.</ref>
The award itself was an engraved glass skull, in reference to the famous graveyard scene in Shakespeare's ''[[Hamlet]]''. Thirteen were awarded, and the award speeches were published.<ref>Interview: "[http://www.offwestend.com/index.php/news/view/199 BRICE STRATFORD talks to us about THE OWLE SCHREAME AWARDS of engraved glass skulls...]" OffWestEnd.com, (2014)</ref> The awards covered all forms of historical theatrical performance.<ref>Rigg, Kate ''[http://theculturetrip.com/europe/united-kingdom/articles/5-reasons-to-follow-the-owle-schreame-theatre-company | 5 Reasons to Follow the Owle Schreame Theatre Company]'', "The Culture Trip", (March 2015)</ref>
==Winners==
The winners were:<ref>Loxton, Howard ''[http://www.britishtheatreguide.info/features/the-owle-schreame-awards-for-i-106/1 | The Owle Schreame Awards for Innovation in Classical Theatre]'', "British Theatre Guide", September 19th (2014)</ref><ref>Elliott, Katerina ''[https://www.mouthlondon.com/arts/owle-schreame-classical-awards-in-a-pub/ | Owle Schreame: Classical Awards in a Pub]'', "Mouth London", September 25th (2014)</ref> *[[Phil Willmott|Gods and Monsters Theatre]], for ''[[The Ring Cycle]] Plays'' *The Merely Players, for the ''Merely Shakespeare'' project *Lazarus Theatre, for ''[[The Tragedy of Mariam]]'' *Footfall, for ''[[King Lear (play)|Lear's Daughters]]'' *Tacit Theatre, for ''[[The Canterbury Tales]]'' *Scaffold Shakespeare, for the ''Play out the Play'' project *The [[Guildhall, London|London Guildhall]], for ''[[Medea (play)|Medea in the Amphitheatre]]'' *Factory Theatre, for ''[[Hamlet]]'' and ''[[The Odyssey]]'' *[[Ben Crystal|Passion in Practice]], for work in ''Original Pronunciation'' *Rift, for the immersive ''[[Macbeth]]'' *The Mummers Unconvention, for their work promoting ''[[Mummers Play|Mummers Plays]]'' *[[King_Edward_VI_School,_Stratford-upon-Avon#Edward.27s_Boys|Edward's Boys]], for ''[[Gallathea]]'' *[[Oswald_Stoll#The_Combat_Veteran_Players|The Combat Veteran Players]], for ''[[Henry V (play)|Henry V]]''
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://owleschreameawards.com/ Official awards site]
[[Category:Awards for classical theatre]] [[Category:Awards established in 2014]] [[Category:2014 establishments in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:2014 establishments in England]] [[Category:British theatre awards]] [[Category:Theatrical organisations in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Theatre in England]] [[Category:British awards]] [[Category:English drama]] [[Category:History of theatre]] [[Category:William Shakespeare]] [[Category:United Kingdom theatre stubs]]

page.title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers

revision.comment: /* top */ I believe the Proceedings Archive migrated from MetaPress to Literatum
revision.text:
{{Infobox journal | italic title = force | title = Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers | cover = | editors = | discipline = [[Mechanical engineering]] | peer-reviewed = | former_names = | abbreviation = Proc. Inst. Mech. Eng. | publisher = [[Institution of Mechanical Engineers]] | country = United Kingdom | frequency = | history = 1847–present | openaccess = | license = | impact = | impact-year = | website = http://www.imeche.org/knowledge/publications | link1 = http://archive.pepublishing.com/home/main.mpx | link1-name = Online access | link2 = | link2-name = | JSTOR = | OCLC = | LCCN = 08018925 | CODEN = PIMLAA | ISSN = | eISSN = }} The '''''Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers''''' were first published by the [[Institution of Mechanical Engineers]] (IMechE) in 1847.<ref>{{citation|title=Journals of the Century|first=Tony|last=Stankus|publisher=Psychology Press|year=2002|isbn=978-0-7890-1134-3|page=378|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=O-1qrN9FlYoC&pg=PA378}}.</ref> The ''Proceedings'' were published under this single title until 1963, when they began to be published in two parts. The ''Proceedings'' have since expanded further, in part by incorporating four journals previously published separately: the ''Proceedings of the Institution of Automobile Engineers'' (in 1971), the ''Journal of the Institution of Locomotive Engineers'' (in 1971), the ''Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science'' (in 1983) and ''Engineering in Medicine'' (in 1989).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://public.metapress.com/download/profiles/imeche/IMechE_Timeline7.pdf |title=IMechE publications timeline on IMechE Proceedings Archive website |year=2011 |accessdate=2011-05-25}}</ref> Sixteen individual parts now make up the ''Proceedings'', as follows:<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.uksagepub.com/imeche |title=IMechE details on SAGE Publications website |year=2011 |accessdate=2011-05-25}}</ref>
*[[Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part A: Journal of Power and Energy|Part A: Journal of Power and Energy]] *[[Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part B: Journal of Engineering Manufacture|Part B: Journal of Engineering Manufacture]] *[[Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science|Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science]] *[[Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering|Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering]] *[[Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part E: Journal of Process Mechanical Engineering|Part E: Journal of Process Mechanical Engineering]] *[[Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part F: Journal of Rail and Rapid Transit|Part F: Journal of Rail and Rapid Transit]] *[[Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part G: Journal of Aerospace Engineering|Part G: Journal of Aerospace Engineering]] *[[Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part H: Journal of Engineering in Medicine|Part H: Journal of Engineering in Medicine]] *[[Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering|Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering]] *[[Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part J: Journal of Engineering Tribology|Part J: Journal of Engineering Tribology]] *[[Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part K: Journal of Multi-body Dynamics|Part K: Journal of Multi-body Dynamics]] *[[Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part L: Journal of Materials: Design and Applications|Part L: Journal of Materials: Design and Applications]] *[[Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part M: Journal of Engineering for the Maritime Environment|Part M: Journal of Engineering for the Maritime Environment]] *[[Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part N: Journal of Nanoengineering and Nanosystems|Part N: Journal of Nanoengineering and Nanosystems]] *[[Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part O: Journal of Risk and Reliability|Part O: Journal of Risk and Reliability]] *[[Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part P: Journal of Sports Engineering and Technology|Part P: Journal of Sports Engineering and Technology]]
In 2010, [[SAGE Publications]] began publishing the Institution's journals on behalf of the IMechE.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.uk.sagepub.com/press/2010/september/23_sep.sp |title=IMechE-SAGE Publications press release |year=2011 |accessdate=2011-05-25}}</ref>
== Abstracting and indexing == As of May 2011, 14 of the journals that make up the ''Proceedings'' were included in the ''[[Journal Citation Reports]]''.<ref name=WoS>{{cite book |year=2011 |chapter=Journals Ranked by Impact: Engineering, Mechanical |title=2010 [[Journal Citation Reports]] |publisher=[[Thomson Reuters]] |edition=Science |accessdate=2011-07-23 |work=Web of Science |postscript=.}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * {{Official website|1=http://www.imeche.org/knowledge/publications}} {{Institution of Mechanical Engineers}} [[Category:Academic journals associated with learned and professional societies]] [[Category:Academic journal series]] [[Category:English-language journals]] [[Category:Engineering journals]] [[Category:Institution of Mechanical Engineers academic journals]] [[Category:Publications established in 1847]] [[Category:SAGE Publications academic journals]] [[Category:1847 establishments in England]]

revision.comment: /* History */transposed items so that "United States" appears at first mention and "US" at later mention, because that order is more logical (minor edit)
revision.text:
[[File:Scopitone 02.jpg|thumb|upright|Scopitone machine]] '''Scopitone''' is a type of [[jukebox]] featuring a [[16 mm film]] component. Scopitone films were a forerunner of [[music video]]s. The Italian [[Cinebox]]/Colorama and Color-Sonics were competing, lesser-known technologies of the time.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scopitonearchive.com/cinebox/index.html|title=Scopitone Archive: Cinebox/Colorama/Cinejukebox|website=Scopitonearchive.com|accessdate=2 August 2018}}</ref>
Based on [[Soundies]] technology developed during [[World War II]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stim.com/Stim-x/9.4/scopitone/scopitone-09.4.html|title=Le Scopitone!|website=Stim.com|accessdate=2 August 2018}}</ref> color [[16 mm film]] clips with a magnetic [[soundtrack]] were designed to be shown in a specially designed jukebox. The main difference between these and the earlier Soundies and [[Snader Telescriptions|Telescriptions]] was the fact that like all modern music videos, all Scopitones featured lip-sync to a pre-recorded track.
Between 1940 and 1946, three-minute musical films called Soundies (produced in [[New York City]], [[Chicago]] and [[Hollywood]]) were displayed on a [[Panoram]], the first coin-operated film jukebox or ''machine music''. These were set up in nightclubs, bars, restaurants and amusement centers.
==History== The first Scopitones were made in France, by a company called [[Cameca]] on Blvd Saint Denis in Courbevoie, among them [[Serge Gainsbourg]]'s "Le poinçonneur des Lilas" (filmed in 1958 in the [[Porte des Lilas (Paris Métro)|Porte des Lilas Métro station]]),<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.forumdesimages.net/fr/alacarte/htm/ACTUALITE/GAINSBOURG.htm |title=Archived copy |access-date=2008-09-06 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051120123449/http://www.forumdesimages.net/fr/alacarte/htm/ACTUALITE/GAINSBOURG.htm |archive-date=2005-11-20 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> [[Johnny Hallyday]]'s "Noir c'est noir" (a cover of [[Los Bravos]]' "[[Black Is Black]]") and the "[[Hully Gully]]" showing a dance around a swimming pool.
Scopitones spread to [[West Germany]], where the [[Kessler Twins|Kessler Sisters]] burst out of twin steamer trunks to sing "Quando Quando" on the dim screen that surmounted the jukebox. Scopitone went on to appear in bars in [[England]], including a coffee bar in [[Swanage]] where "[[Telstar (song)|Telstar]]" was a favourite. By 1964, approximately 500 machines were installed in the United States.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.loti.com/fifties_jukebox/Scoptione_The_Visual_Jukebox.htm |title=Archived copy |access-date=2008-05-22 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080605070925/http://www.loti.com/fifties_jukebox/Scoptione_The_Visual_Jukebox.htm |archive-date=2008-06-05 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> By 1966, reportedly 800 machines were installed in bars and nightclubs in the US, at a cost of $3500 apiece.<ref name="Billboard">{{citation |title=Cinema Juke Box: Just a Novelty? |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UykEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA48&lpg=PA48&dq=cinema+juke+box:+just+a+novelty?&source=bl&ots=Y8qYox1yRZ&sig=wAl6yCm-w8y5owNccYsu0nnthss&hl=en&sa=X&ei=_FKbUK7aJaXmiwK15oHgDQ&ved=0CDIQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=cinema%20juke%20box%3A%20just%20a%20novelty%3F&f=false |work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |first1=Ray |last1=Brack|page=48 |date=July 10, 1965 |accessdate=November 7, 2012 }}.</ref>
Several well-known acts of the 1960s appear in Scopitone films, ranging from the earlier part of the decade [[The Exciters]] ("[[Tell Him (Bert Berns song)|Tell Him]]") and [[Neil Sedaka]] ("Calendar Girl") to [[Bobby Vee]] ("[[The Night Has a Thousand Eyes (song)|The Night Has a Thousand Eyes]]" and "[[Baby Face (1926 song)|Baby Face]]") and [[Procol Harum]] ("[[A Whiter Shade of Pale]]") later on. In one Scopitone recording, [[Dionne Warwick]] lay on a white shag rug with an offstage fan urging her to sing "[[Walk On By (song)|Walk On By]]". Another had [[Nancy Sinatra]] and a troupe of go-go girls shimmy to "[[These Boots Are Made for Walkin']]". Inspired by [[burlesque]], [[bombshell (sex symbol)|blonde bombshell]] [[Joi Lansing]] performed "Web of Love" and "The Silencer", and [[Julie London]] sang "Daddy" against a backdrop of strippers.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6Vt-xeVrI3c|title=Daddy by Julie London|date=18 July 2006|accessdate=2 August 2018|publisher=[[YouTube]]}}</ref> The artifice of such scenes led [[Susan Sontag]] to identify Scopitone films as "part of the canon of [[Camp (style)|Camp]]" in her 1964 essay "[[Notes on 'Camp']]".
The medium's inability to lure the superstar [[British Invasion]] acts of the era was a factor in its demise,<ref name="AVCLUB">{{citation |title=Let's all watch the Scopitone! 15 never-too-popular obsolete entertainment formats |url=http://www.avclub.com/articles/lets-all-watch-the-scopitone-15-nevertoopopular-ob,57012/ |publisher=[[The A.V. Club]]'' |first1=Noel |last1=Murray |first2=Keith |last2=Phipps |first3=Scott |last3=Tobias |date=June 6, 2011 |accessdate=June 6, 2011 }}.</ref> as well as the declining taste of the subject matter. Several sources claim that [[The Back Porch Majority]] film for ''Mighty Mississippi'' from their album ''Riverboat Days'' (1964) was equally instrumental in bringing down the format for its so-called indecency. Against the wishes of the group and its producer [[Randy Sparks]] scenes of girls in 19th century period dress hiking up their [[hoop skirt]]s were inserted into the performance. By the time protests could be raised and the offending material excised, the film had already gone out.
Even though the popularity of the Scopitone had faded away by the end of the 1960s,<ref name="AVCLUB" />the same concept was still in limited use throughout the 1970s by acts such as the [[The Carpenters|Carpenters]] and [[ABBA]] both of whose early productions were shot on 16mm film before transitioning to [[videotape]]. The last official film for a Scopitone was made at the end of 1978.
In 2006, French singer [[Mareva Galanter]] released several videos which mimic the Scopitone style. Galenta's album ''Ukuyéyé'' features several songs in the French [[Yé-yé]] style. She also recently hosted a weekly French television program called "Do you do you Scopitone" on the [[Paris Première]] channel.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.paris-premiere.fr/cms/display.jsp?id=p2_802761|title=6play : Replay Paris Première et direct des émissions et séries|website=Paris-premiere.fr|accessdate=2 August 2018}}</ref>
In 1990, a selection of Scopitones was screened at the Jewel Box theater in [[Seattle]] by [[Dennis Nyback]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://moviemorlocks.com/2010/07/01/scopitone-a-go-go/|title=Scopitone A Go-Go|website=Moviemorlocks.com|accessdate=2 August 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://scopitones.blogs.com/scopitonescom/2010/12/the-day-i-discovered-scopitones-with-jack-stevenson-dennis-nyback-films.html|title=Scopitones.com: The Day I Discovered Scopitones With Jack Stevenson - Dennis Nyback Films|website=Scopitones.blogs.com|accessdate=2 August 2018}}</ref>
As of 2012, one of the few Scopitones not in a museum or private collection in the United States is at [[Third Man Records]] in [[Nashville, Tennessee]].<ref>[http://blogs.tennessean.com/tunein/2012/11/20/third-man-records-opens-novelties-lounge-on-black-friday/?repeat=w3tc "Third Man Records opens ‘Novelties Lounge’ on Black Friday"], ''[[The Tennessean]]''</ref> Many Scopitone films have been released on [[DVD]] or made available on the [[internet]].<ref name="AVCLUB" />
==See also== {{Music video}} * [[Panoram]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons category| scopitone}} * [http://www.scopitones.blogs.com/ Scopitones.com has many Scopitones available for viewing, downloading & purchasing] * [http://www.scopitonearchive.com/ Scopitone archive] * [https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=5630027 NPR: Rise and Fall of the Scopitone Jukebox]
